FacilityName: Island Equipment Company Gas Manufacturing Plant

_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Other Chemical and Allied Products Merchant Wholesalers

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



REGISTRATION INFORMATION

This is a 5 Year Anniversary Resubmission, and our company has narrowed down the regulated substance from two to only one , which is CHLORINE, CAS Number 7782-50-5. All the sections from the original submission of 11/10/2010, that were related to Sulfur Dioxide, CAS Number 7446-09-5,which we no longer import,store and distribute, has now been removed and/or deleted in this resubmission..  



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES

Island Equipment Company is located in Guam. The facility stores and distributed chlorine and employs approximately 23 persons at this location. Island Equipment Company has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and safety.  Island Equipment Company's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substance.

 

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

A maximum of 32,200 lbs of chlorine are stored at the facility.  The substance is not used for any processes and no maintenance is performed on the cylinders while on site.     



HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary:

Scenario Description: Per the EPA Regulations, one worst-case release scenario has been defined for the covered substance.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.  



Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary:

Scenario Description: Per the EPA Regulations, one alternative-case release scenario has been defined in the covered substances.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.  



Risk Considerations:

Although the storage and distribution of chlorine has inherent potential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; Island Equipment Company has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs

to make the worst-case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the company and facility personnel to make this worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event (e.g., In the event of a release, sudden rupture and flashing of ammonia would be highly turbulent. Turbulence causes entrainment of air and the released vapor dilutes much more quickly than is shown in the model).



The history of Island Equipment Company (i.e., no RMP-applicable chlorine releases in the last five years or even in the past many years) reflects the adequacy of the design and diligence of the facility staff in safely storing chlorine.

 

RISK MANAGEMENT PREVENTION PROGRAM

As part of the implementation of the RMP Program 3, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by Island Equipment Company to manage safety issues associated with the storage and distribution of chlorine. Prevention Program 3 elements include:



   40CFR68.65 Process Safety Information

   40CFR68.67 Process Hazard Analysis (PHA))

   40CFR68.69 Operating Procedures (OP)

   40CFR68.71 Training (TRN)

   40CFR68.73 Mechanical Integrity (MI)   

   40CFR68.75 Management of Change (MOC)

   40CFR68.77 Pre-Startup Review (PSSR)

   40CFR68.79 Compliance Audits (CA)

   40CFR68.81 Incident Investigation (II)

   40CFR68.83 Employee Participation (EP)

   40CFR68.85 Hot Work Permit (HWP)

   40CFR68.87 Contractors (CO)

   40CFR68.90 Emergency Planning & Response (EP&R)







FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no RMP-applicable releases of chlorine at the facility in at least the past five (5) years.  



FLAMMABLES: WORST CASE

The use of flammable materials at Island Equipment Company facility is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this sect

ion is not applicable. 





FLAMMABLES: ALTERNATIVE RELEASE

The use of flammable materials at Island Equipment Company facility is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Island Equipment Company is extremely diligent in the handling of chlorine.
